questions.text: Drug capable of causing ocular hypotension with apnea in infant is
questions.solution:
Brimonidine is an anti glaucoma drug which comes under the class of alpha 2 agonists and its major side effect is CNS depression and apnea in infants.

α2 AGONISTS: Apraclonidine, Brimonidine

MOA: It ↓ Aqueous formation

Side effects

  • Lid retraction
  • Dry Mouth
  • Ocular burning and allergic conjunctivitis
  • Brimonidine is less likely to cause ocular allergy
  • These can cause CNS depression and apnea in neonates and are contraindicated in children <2 years
  • Mode of actions for different anti-glaucoma drugs

Side effect profile of:

A. Acetazolamide: Systemic symptoms like Metabolic acidosis

B. Latanoprost: Iris hyperpigmentation, Hypertrichosis, Uveitis, Cystoid macular edema, Reactivation of herpetic keratitis

D. Apraclonidine: Follicular conjunctivitis, Mydriasis, Eyelid retraction

questions.text: A patient whose cultures are positive for diphtheria but does not have signs and symptoms has come up for a consultation. Which of the following drugs will you give for this condition?
questions.solution:
Erythromycin is used as a first choice drug for

  1. Atypical pneumonia caused by Mycoplasma pneumoniae: rate of recovery is hastened.
  2. Whooping cough: a 1-2 week course of erythromycin is the most effective treatment for eradicating B. pertussis from upper respiratory tract. However, the effect on the symptoms depends on the stage of disease when treatment is started.

(a) Prophylactic: during the 10 day incubation period-disease is prevented.

(b) Catarrhal stage: which lasts for about a week-erythromycin may abort the next stage or reduce its duration and severity.

(c) Paroxysmal stage: lasting 2-4 weeks- no effect on the duration and severity of 'croup' despite eradication of the causative organism.

(d) Convalescent stage: during which 'croup' gradually resolves (4-12 weeks)-is not modified.

  1. Chancroid : Erythromycin 2 g/day for 7 days is one of the first line drugs, as effective as single dose azithromycin or ceftriaxone
  2. Diphtheria: Erythromycin is given to contacts of diphtheria cases as prophylaxis as well as for treatment purposes.
  3. Chlamydia
  4. Legionella

questions.text: The drug buspirone, used in cases of anxiety, acts as an agonist on the receptor
questions.solution:
Buspirone It is the first azapirone, a class of selective anti anxiety drugs, distinctly different from BZDs. Buspirone:

  • Does not produce significant sedation or cognitive/functional impairment.
  • Does not interact with BZD receptors or modify GABAergic transmission.
  • Does not produce tolerance or dependence; no rebound anxiety or withdrawal symptoms on stoppage.
  • Does not suppress BZD or barbiturate withdrawal syndrome.
  • Has no muscle relaxant or anticonvulsant activity.

The mechanism of anxiolytic action is not clearly known, but may be dependent on its selective partial agonistic action on 5-HT1A receptors. By stimulating presynaptic 5-HT1A autoreceptors, it reduces the activity of dorsal raphe serotonergic neurons.

Other options:

B.5HT1B/1D agonists: Triptans like Sumatriptan used in treatment of Migraine

C.5HT2 agonists: Lorcaserin, an anorexic is used in obesity

D.5HT3 agonists: Ondansetron, Palonosetron are 5HT3 agonists used as antiemetic.

questions.text: Carbapenem with maximum seizure risk is:
questions.solution:
Carbapenems

These include imipenem, doripenem, meropenem, faropenem and ertapenem.

These have a wide spectrum of activity including gram positive cocci, gram negative rods as well as anaerobes. For the treatment of pseudomonas (meropenem is most active whereas ertapenem is least) infections, these drugs should be combined with aminoglycosides.

Carbapenems are β-lactamase resistant and are drugs of choice for Enterobacter, Klebsiella and acinetobacter species. These are the only β -lactams which are reliably efficacious against ESBL (extended spectrum β-lactamase) producing organisms and are thus drugs of choice for ESBL- producing bacteria.

Imipenem is rapidly inactivated by renal dehydropeptidase I, so it is combined with cilastatin, an inhibitor of this enzyme. Cilastatin increases the half life of imipenem and also inhibits the formation of nephrotoxic metabolites.Main adverse effects of imipenem-cilastatin combination include seizures and gastrointestinal distress. Meropenem, doripenem, ertapenem are not metabolized by renal dehydropeptidase and are less likely to cause seizures. Ertapenem is very long acting and is inactive against Pseudomonas.

choices.text: It decreases the risk of neutropenia in patients on anti- cancer therapy
It is a short acting drug

questions.text: Which of the following statements about pegfilgrastim is true?
questions.solution:
Filgrastim

It is a recombinant human granulocyte-colony stimulating factor (G-CSF). Started one day after myelosuppressive chemotherapy and injected s.c. or i.v. (5 μg/kg) daily, till neutrophil count normalizes, may be used to shorten recovery time from neutropenia. It is a long acting drug due to its pegylated form. It is administered as parenterally(S/C or IV)

MOA: Recombinant G CSF drug

Uses:

  • Neutropenia in HIV
  • Myelodysplasia
  • Chemotherapy induced agranulocytosis
  • Aplastic anemia

S/E: Bone pain

Recombinant GM CSF drug: Sargramostim

questions.text: Which of the following anaesthetic agent is not painful on intravenous administration
questions.solution:
Ketamine is a strong analgesic drug and is water soluble. Its injection is not painful.

  • Propofol and etomidate solutions have to be made in oil due to poor water solubility, so these injections are quite painful.(Option B,C)
  • Methohexitone can cause hyperalgesia.(Option D)

questions.text: Reason for preferring Cis-Atracurium over atracurium is:
questions.solution:
Cisatracurium

This R-Cis, R-Cis enantiomer of atracurium is nearly 4 times more potent, slower in onset(Option A ruled out), but similar in duration of action.(Option C ruled out)

Like atracurium it undergoes Hofmann elimination(Option D ruled out), but in contrast to the racemate, it is not hydrolysed by plasma cholinesterase and hepatic metabolism is limited, so that less of the toxic metabolite is formed.

Most importantly, it does not provoke histamine release and side effects are fewer. Currently, cisatracurium is one of the preferred muscle relaxants, especially for liver/kidney disease patients and for the elderly.

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication to the use of beta blockers:
questions.solution:
Limitations of Non-selective β -Blockers

  • Contraindicated in bronchial asthma due to their bronchoconstrictor action.
  • Hypoglycemia is commonly observed in diabetic patients receiving insulin and oral hypoglycemic drugs. Symptoms of hypoglycemia (like tachycardia, sweating and tremors) are due to sympathetic stimulation that act as warning signs for the patient. Beta blockers mask these symptoms (except sweating because it is mediated by a sympathetic cholinergic system) and patients can go directly into a coma. Further, these agents delay the recovery from hypoglycemia due to inhibition of β2mediated hyperglycemia. These drugs are therefore contraindicated in diabetic patients.
  • On long term use non selective β blockers can adversely affect serum lipid profile and can cause glucose intolerance.
  • By causing vasoconstriction (β2 is vasodilatory), these drugs can worsen peripheral vascular disease (contraindicated in Raynaud's disease).
  • These drugs can impair exercise capacity due to blockade of skeletal vascular β2 receptors.

List of non selective beta blockers:

questions.text: Which of the following IV anaesthetic agents does not cause cardiac depression
questions.solution:
Etomidate: It is another induction anaesthetic (0.2-0.5 mg/kg) which has a briefer duration of action (4-8 min) than thiopentone; produces little cardiovascular and respiratory depression, but motor restlessness and rigidity is more prominent as are pain on injection or nausea and vomiting on recovery. It is a poor analgesic and has not found much favour except for patients with compromised cardiovascular status.

Options B,C,D: Propofol, Methohexitone and Thiopentone have cardiac side effects and hence not used in cardiac patients.

questions.text: Which of the following inhalational anaesthetic agents is with highest respiratory irritation?
questions.solution:
Desflurane

  • It has minimum blood gas partition coefficient and therefore is the fastest inducing agent.
  • It has very high vapour pressure. Its boiling point is 23°C; therefore it boils at room temperature. It requires special vaporizers due to this property.
  • It produces cardiovascular effects similar to isoflurane except coronary steal phenomenon.
  • Induction with desflurane is unpleasant. It causes maximum irritation to airways. As it can lead to coughing, breath holding and laryngospasm.
  • It can also be used in day care surgery.

questions.text: Mannitol is used in the management of:-
questions.solution:
Mannitol is very helpful in lowering of intraocular pressure in cases of Acute congestive glaucoma.

MOA: Increases the extracellular oncotic pressure hence extracting water from cells and tissues.

Uses

Its indications are:

  1. Increased intracranial or intraocular tension (acute congestive glaucoma, head injury, stroke, etc
  2. To maintain GFR and urine flow in impending acute renal failure
  3. To counteract low osmolality of plasma and ECF due to rapid haemodialysis or peritoneal dialysis (dialysis disequilibrium).

Mannitol is contraindicated in renal insufficiency, acute tubular necrosis, anuria, pulmonary edema; acute left ventricular failure, CHF and cerebral haemorrhage.(Options A,C,D ruled out)

The most common side effect is headache. Nausea and vomiting may occur; hypersensitivity reactions are rare.

questions.text: Hypertension and pulmonary edema associated with scorpion sting is managed by:-
questions.solution:
• Scorpion sting is a dreadful medical emergency.
  • Scorpion stings cause a wide range of symptoms, from severe local reactions to cardiovascular, respiratory and neurological manifestations.
  • Alpha-receptors play a vital role in the pathogenesis of cardiac failure and pulmonary edema due to scorpion sting.
  • Prazosin is a selective alpha-1 adrenergic receptor blocker. It dilates veins and arterioles, thereby reducing preload and left ventricular impedance without rise in heart rate and renin secretion. It also inhibits sympathetic outflow in the central nervous system. It enhances insulin secretion, which is inhibited by venom action. It has also been found useful even in cases with hypotension. Thus, its pharmacological properties can antagonize the hemodynamic, hormonal and metabolic effects of scorpion venom action

choices.text: Adverse effects of one drug may be reduced by the other drug
Two drugs with different pharmacokinetics can be combined easily
Dose of one drug can be altered independently as per requirement
Adverse effect can be ascribed to a single drug

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding fixed dose combinations of drugs?
questions.solution:
Fixed dose combinations (FDCs) of drugs

A large number of pharmaceutical preparations contain two or more drugs in a fixed dose ratio. Advantages offered by these are:

  1. Convenience and better patient compliance- when all the components present in the FDC are actually needed by the patient and their amounts are appropriate.
  2. Certain drug combinations are synergistic, e.g. sulfamethoxazole + trimethoprim; levodopa + carbidopa/benserazide
  3. The therapeutic effect of two components being the same may add up while the side effects being different may not.
  4. The side effect of one component may be counteracted by the other, e.g. a thiazide + a potassium sparing diuretic.
  5. Combined formulation ensures that a single drug will not be administered. This is important in the treatment of tuberculosis, HIV-AIDS and falciparum malaria

Option B: Drugs with similar pharmacokinetics need to be combined together so that both the drugs attain peak concentration and action simultaneously.

Option C: This statement is false

Option D: Adverse effect if present can be because of both the drugs.

questions.text: Mechanism of action of Oseltamivir and Zanamivir is:
questions.solution:
Oseltamivir This is the most commonly used anti-influenza virus drug now.

MOA: Oseltamivir acts by inhibiting influenza virus neuraminidase enzyme which is needed for release of progeny virions from the infected cell.

Uses: Oseltamivir (as well as zanamivir) is the most effective drug for influenza A, including H5N1 and H1N1 strains, as well as influenza B.

Dose: therapeutic 75 mg oral BD for 5 days; prophylactic75 mg OD.

Side effects are nausea and abdominal pain due to gastric irritation (reduced by taking the drug with food), headache, weakness, sadness, diarrhoea, cough and insomnia. Skin reactions have been reported.

questions.text: You are a doctor working with doctors without borders. Your latest assignment would be a 6 months service at an African village. You being cautious, take mefloquine prophylaxis. With its consumption, due to its quality of high protein binding, you would expect:
questions.solution:
Oral absorption of MQ is good but peak concentrations are reached 5-15 hours. It is highly plasma protein bound and Concentrated in many organs including liver, lung and intestines. Extensive metabolism occurs in the liver and it is primarily secreted in bile. Considerable enterohepatic circulation of MQ and its tissue binding accounts for the long t½ which is 2-3 weeks.

Option A: High plasma protein binding means the drug would remain in the intravascular compartment and hence won’t undergo glomerular filtration

Option B: High plasma protein binding means the drug would remain in the intravascular compartment and hence will have a low Volume of distribution

Option C: High plasma protein binding increases the duration of action

Option D: High plasma protein binding would lead to more drug interactions as many drugs may bind to a similar protein.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used for smoking cessation?
questions.solution:
Varenicline : This α4β2 subtype NR selective partial agonist has been marketed as oral tablets in many countries to help smoking cessation.

MOA: Evidence has shown that the reward (reinforcing) action of nicotine is exerted through the α4β2 subtype of neuronal NRs which are mainly localized in nucleus accumbens and other mesolimbic areas.

Activation of these NRs by nicotine induces DA release which produces feelings of satisfaction/reward and has a reinforcing effect.

Since varenicline is a partial agonist at these receptors, it provides some level of nicotine substitution, but blocks the reward effect of smoking.

Uses: Clinically it has been found to reduce craving as well as nicotine withdrawal symptoms in those who stop smoking.

Side effects: Utility of varenicline is limited by its side effects, which are mood changes, irrational behaviour, appetite and taste disturbances, sleep disorder and agitation. Warning has been issued that it may promote suicidal thoughts.

Option B,C,D:

choices.text: It is used for short-bowel syndrome

questions.text: It is your first day as an intern in the medicine department and in the first case sheet you read, the patient was given teduglutide. On reading about this drug, you would learn all the following about the drug, except?
questions.solution:
Teduglutide

  • It is a recombinant analog of human glucagon like peptide 2(GLP 2)(Option B)
  • It is used for the treatment of adults with short bowel syndrome(Option A)
  • It works by promoting mucosal growth and possibly restoring gastric emptying and secretion and is a gut hormone.(Option D)
  • It is given by subcutaneous route
  • It is long acting drug because it is resistant to degradation by DPP-4

choices.text: Cilastatin prevents degradation of imipenem in kidney
Inhibits the enzymes that digest imipenem in stomach

questions.text: Cilastatin is given in combination with imipenem because:-
questions.solution:
A limiting feature of imipenem is its rapid hydrolysis by the enzyme dehydropeptidase I located on the brush border of renal tubular cells.

An innovative solution to this problem is its combination with cilastatin, a reversible inhibitor of dehydropeptidase I, which has matched pharmacokinetics with imipenem (t½ of both is 1 hr) and protects it.

Options B,C,D are not the correct reasons why Imipenem is given with Cilastatin.

questions.text: A 49 year old male, came into your clinic with complaints of diplopia, slurred speech, difficulty in breathing, drooping of eyelids and generalized fatigue by the end of the day. The complaints. Worsened progressively throughout the day and the patient comparatively felt better with rest. You suspect myasthenia gravis as the diagnosis. Which of the following agents can be used to differentiate between myasthenia gravis and cholinergic crisis?
questions.solution:
The two types of weakness require opposite treatments. They can be differentiated by edrophonium test-

Inject edrophonium (2 mg. i.v.)

  1. Improvement→myasthenic crisis
  2. No improvement or worsening→cholinergic crisis

questions.text: Drug inhibiting granulocyte migration is:
questions.solution:
Colchicine

Colchicine is neither analgesic nor antiinflammatory, But it specifically suppresses gouty inflammation. It does not inhibit the synthesis or promote the excretion of uric acid.

An acute attack of gout is started by the precipitation of urate crystals in the synovial fluid. On being engulfed by the synovial cells, they release mediators and start an inflammatory response.

Chemotactic factors are produced → granulocytes migrate into the joint; they phagocytose urate crystals and release a glycoprotein which aggravates the inflammation by:

  • Increasing lactic acid production from inflammatory cells → local pH is reduced → more urate crystals are precipitated.
  • Releasing lysosomal enzymes which cause joint destruction.

MOA: Colchicine does not affect phagocytosis of urate crystals, but inhibits release of chemotactic factors and of the glycoprotein, thus suppressing the subsequent events. By binding to fibrillar protein tubulin, it inhibits granulocyte migration into the inflamed joint and thus interrupts the vicious cycle. Other actions of colchicine are:

(a) Antimitotic: causes metaphase arrest by binding to microtubules of mitotic spindle.

(b) Increases gut motility through neural mechanisms.

Optionwise explanation:

choices.text: Competitive Non-depolarizing block at Nm cholinergic receptors
Non-Competitive, Non-depolarizing block at Nm cholinergic receptors
Competitive depolarizing block at Nm cholinergic receptors
NON-Competitive, depolarizing block at Nm cholinergic receptors

questions.text: d-tubocurarine is a toxic alkaloid historically known for its use as arrow poison. It has neuromuscular blocking effects. It is the first curare drug and curare like drugs have the property to cause:
questions.solution:
D-tubocurarine is a skeletal muscle relaxant that acts by competitive inhibition of Nm receptors at neuron-muscular junction.

Depolarizing Muscle Relaxants

Key Points:

  • Rapid Onset: Acts within 30–60 seconds.
  • Short Duration: Lasts 5–10 minutes.
  • Side Effects: Hyperkalemia, malignant hyperthermia, muscle pain, bradycardia.
  • Only depolarizing agent in clinical use.

Non-Depolarizing Muscle Relaxants

questions.text: A 48 year old male came with complaints of symptoms typical of an anginal attack. Which of the medications that can be used in the treatment of angina and its prevention in this patient, acts through opening of cardiac potassium channels?
questions.solution:
Nicorandil This dual mechanism antianginal drug activates ATP sensitive K+ channels (KATP) in smooth muscle membrane thereby hyperpolarizing and relaxing it. The vasodilator action is partly antagonized by the K+ channel blocker glibenclamide. Like nitrates it also acts as a NO donor-relaxes blood vessels by increasing cGMP. Thus, arterial dilatation is coupled with vasodilatation, and both cardiac preload as well as afterload are reduced. Coronary flow is increased.

Rivaro XA ban is a factor XA antagonist.

questions.text: Mechanism of action of triazoles
questions.solution:
IMIDAZOLES AND TRIAZOLES (AZOLES)

These are presently the most extensively used antifungal drugs.

The azoles have broad-spectrum antifungal activity covering dermatophytes, Candida, other fungi involved indeep mycosis (except mucor), Nocardia and Leishmania.The azoles act by inhibiting fungal cytochrome P450 enzyme 'lanosterol 14-demethylase' and thus impair ergosterol synthesis This leads to a cascade of membrane abnormalities in the fungus. The lower host toxicity of triazoles compared to imidazoles has correlated with their lower affinity for mammalian CYP450 enzymes and lesser propensity to inhibit mammalian sterol synthesis.

Following is a list of all classes of anti fungals :

questions.text: Fluoroquinolone with highest oral bioavailability:
questions.solution: Levofloxacin It is the active levo(S) isomer of ofloxacin having improved activity against Strep. pneumoniae,tuberculosis and some other gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria. Anaerobes are moderately susceptible. Oral bioavailability of levofloxacin is nearly 100%; oral and i.v. doses are similar. It is mainly excreted unchanged, and a single daily dose is sufficient because of slower elimination and higher potency.

questions.text: A nursing mother presented with fever and breast tenderness after two weeks postpartum, which oral antibiotics is ideal for her condition?
questions.solution:
Dicloxacillin

Oxacillin, cloxacillin and dicloxacillin are semisynthetic penicillin congeners that are markedly resistant to cleavage by penicillinase. These drugs are not substitutes for penicillin G in the treatment of diseases amenable to it and are not active against enterococci or Listeria. Oral administration is not a substitute for the parenteral routein the treatment of serious staphylococcal infections.

Pharmacological Properties. The isoxazolyl penicillins are potentinhibitors of the growth of most penicillinase-producing staphylococci.These agents are absorbed rapidly butincompletely (30%-80%) from the GI tract.

All these congeners are bound to plasma albumin to a great extent (~90%-95%); none is removed from the circulation to a significant degree by hemodialysis.

The half-lives for all are between 30 and 60 min. No dosing adjustments are needed for patients with renal failure.

About 20% of amoxicillin is protein bound in plasma, a value similar to that for ampicillin.
